misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for an unrelated problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three double values, which corresponds to an average-acceleration problem, rather than reading five integers as required for summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this task is to read initial velocity, final velocity, and time (v0, v1, t) as doubles to compute average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly five integers from the user (e.g., using nextInt five times or in a loop) representing arbitrary numbers, not physics quantities.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions 'Enter v0, v1, and t' instead of asking for 5 integers
Uses nextDouble three times instead of nextInt five times
Only three input values are consumed instead of five
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of a template solution for a different textbook problem (average acceleration) and not aligning the input handling with the current task requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and change the input section to ask for and read 5 integers (using nextInt), either one by one or inside a loop.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to input requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and variable names (v0, v1, t) match a standard acceleration example and do not mention five integers, strongly suggesting the student is solving a different problem.

evidence.note: Reads three double values v0, v1, and t instead of five integers as specified by the problem.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.description: The solution does not use any loop structure to process multiple inputs; it simply reads three values once and applies a formula, which does not match the requirement to process five numbers (and is typically done with a loop in CS1).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this problem can be solved with a single direct formula on three inputs, so a loop to handle multiple numbers is unnecessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle five inputs in a scalable way, especially when filtering or accumulating, you should use a loop (for or while) that runs five times, reading each number and processing it.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the program
Inputs are read a fixed small number of times entirely unrelated to '5 integers'
No repeated processing of input values
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment with the task of processing a collection of inputs, likely because the student implemented a different single-formula problem where looping is not required.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that iterates exactly five times, reading each integer in the loop body and applying the required logic (such as checking if it is even and updating a sum).
related_concepts: Iterating over a fixed count of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete absence of any loop combined with handling only three values indicates the student did not apply the intended looping pattern for multiple inputs.

evidence.note: Inputs are handled directly without any loop structure; the code just reads three values once and computes a formula.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number check using modulo and conditionals
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0 in an if statement); it simply computes an acceleration expression on three inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to compute an average acceleration, not to filter inputs based on evenness, so they did not include any modulo or conditional logic for parity.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, the program must test each input with an expression like n % 2 == 0 inside an if statement and include it in the sum only if this condition is true.
symptoms: No use of the % operator in the code
No if or conditional logic related to parity or even/odd checking
Calculation uses arithmetic on v0, v1, t unrelated to number parity
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a different problem that does not involve conditional filtering, suggesting they did not attend to the requirement to sum only even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, use an if statement with n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers and add only those to the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code entirely lacks modulo or any conditional filtering, while the task explicitly requires summing only even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Performs a simple arithmetic computation and outputs it, with no if statements or % operator to filter even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Computes a single physics formula instead of accumulating a sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: Rather than maintaining a running sum of even numbers, the code computes a single acceleration value ( (v1 - v0) / t ) and prints it, which does not satisfy the requirement to sum even inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the goal is to calculate and print the average acceleration from three values, not to accumulate and output the sum of selected (even) integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should initialize an accumulator variable (e.g., sum = 0), add each even input to this accumulator as it is processed, and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by this sum.
symptoms: No integer accumulator variable (e.g., sum) is declared or updated
Only one arithmetic expression (v1 - v0) / t is evaluated once
Printed message refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely copied or adapted a different example focused on average acceleration, so they used a direct formula and message instead of designing an accumulation pattern.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the acceleration formula with an integer sum accumulator that starts at 0 and is increased by each even number encountered; then print the sum with an appropriate message.
related_concepts: Designing output messages to match problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Variable names and printed text clearly target a different physics problem, and there is no sign of any summation logic.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Uses a single acceleration computation and prints it, with no running sum variable or text related to summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements (Wrong Program Implemented)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating average acceleration (reading 3 doubles v0, v1, t) instead of the required program for finding the sum of even numbers among 5 integers. This represents a critical failure in task analysis and algorithm design, addressing an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the objective was to calculate acceleration, or submitted code intended for a different, unrelated assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem required reading exactly 5 integer inputs, using a loop structure, checking each input for parity (evenness), and accumulating only the even values.
symptoms: The class name is 'AccelerationCalculator'.
The program prompts for and reads only 3 inputs.
The inputs are treated as doubles, not integers.
The core logic calculates acceleration (v1 - v0) / t, not a sum.
Crucial elements like loops and conditionals (for parity check) are missing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to align the implemented solution with the stated problem prompt. Likely submission error or severe misunderstanding of the assignment scope.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read all assignment requirements. Ensure the code you write addresses the specific inputs, calculations, and outputs requested in the prompt (e.g., reading 5 integers and checking for evenness).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code directly implements an acceleration formula and reads variables completely unrelated to the required task. There is no ambiguity.

evidence.note: The prompt asks for 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of entering 5 integers for summing even numbers.
Reads 3 doubles, not 5 integers, violating input quantity and data type requirements.
The calculation implements the acceleration formula, not integer summation and parity checking logic.

misconceptions.name: Missing Required Control Structures (Loop and Conditional)
misconceptions.description: The student's code contains neither a loop (to process 5 inputs) nor a conditional statement (to check if a number is even), which are the fundamental control structures required to solve the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student failed to realize that iteration and selection structures are necessary to process multiple inputs and filter them based on a condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A loop (e.g., `for` or `while`) needs to iterate 5 times, and an `if` statement with the modulo operator (`% 2 == 0`) is required inside the loop to check for even numbers.
symptoms: Code executes sequentially without repetition.
No use of the remainder operator (%) to check parity.
No `if` or `for`/`while` keywords related to the required logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented the wrong problem entirely, leading to the absence of the correct control flow logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review lessons on iteration (loops) and selection (conditionals) in Java to understand how to handle multiple inputs and filter data based on specific criteria.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The required logic structures (loops, if statements checking parity) are entirely absent from the provided source code.

evidence.note: The entire main method lacks any loop or conditional structure to process five numbers or check for evenness.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (acceleration calculator) instead of the assigned sum of even numbers problem. This suggests either a copy-paste error, submission of wrong file, or fundamental confusion about the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration calculation problem that reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and summing only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration instead of summing even numbers
Class name is 'AccelerationCalculator' instead of something related to the problem
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
No accumulator for summing values
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem, indicating either a file management error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) read 5 integers using a loop, (2) check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulate the sum of even numbers, and (4) print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with no overlap in logic, input format, or output requirements with the assigned problem (sum of even numbers).
